title: eyethinkdata_vignette
text: several functions beginning data_ read multiple data files merge R object. commonly used data_collator_gorilla(). pass name folder contains downloads gorilla. downloads can .zip files unzipped folders contain gorilla .csv files. example:  run function, tell name folder contains downloaded items, leave blank OS ask choose folder. Remember give function folder contains folders raw data . now list called data contains several data.tables. data$data_task contains data gorilla tasks, blue blobs experiment. raw data gorilla collated together, columns added. example, pid participant identity (anonymized). rt reaction time column. another data.table called data$data_q info experiment questionnaires. deal questionnaire data section . Note can download questionnaire data gorilla website wide (one row per person) long format. Whichever choose, function compile data different questionnaires, adding columns wide format, rows long. type also returned data_qtype. Wide format might useful going immediately analyse data , especially using excel SPSS. going processing using eyethinkdata r functions, choose long format look setions . Finally, used mouse eye tracking plugins, data data$data_continuous
code: library(eyethinkdata) ## Loading required package: ggplot2 ## Loading required package: data.table data <- data_collator_gorilla("gorilla_data") knitr::kable( head(data$data_task),)

what: Task data - extracting stimuli, conditions and behaviour
title: eyethinkdata_vignette
text: ’re going extract, plot analyse data example IAT experiment. first step analysing data pick rows columns want experiment. contain information trial conditions stimuli, information participants’ responses. First identify rows key events, pick columns important information. ’s filter IAT data
code: iat_data <-  data$data_task[metadata %in% c("congruent","incongruent") & # row selection                               Attempt==1 & display=="trials",  # row selection                              .(pid, trial=Trial.Number, # columns                                  congruency=metadata,accuracy=Correct,rt,   # columns                                    item=paste0(na.omit(ImageCentre),na.omit(TextCentre)))]           # figure out what block came first for each person iat_data[,firstblock:=.SD[c(1)]$congruency,by=pid]  knitr::kable(head(iat_data))

previous_headings: Task data - extracting stimuli, conditions and behaviour
title: eyethinkdata_vignette
text: Now can plot data generic plotting function, pirateye(). name columns/conditions want plot x axis, colour contrast.  Since dot per trial, bit crowded. can first average people, also turn elements pirateye, set options flipping coordinates  connect conditions lines
code: pirateye(data=iat_data[accuracy==1 & rt<2000], # trim incorrect trials and outliers          colour_condition = "congruency",x_condition = "firstblock",dv = "rt") pirateye(data=iat_data[accuracy==1 & rt<2000],          colour_condition = "congruency",x_condition = "firstblock",dv = "rt",          pid_average = T,  # average over participants' conditions          violin = F,bar=T,cflip = T)  # no violins but draw some bars and flip axes pirateye(data=iat_data[accuracy==1 & rt<2000],          colour_condition = "congruency",x_condition = "firstblock",dv = "rt",          dots=F,line=T,violin=F)  # no dots but draw some bars

previous_headings: Task data - extracting stimuli, conditions and behaviour
title: eyethinkdata_vignette
text: can analyse data afex aov_ex package, plot results plot_model(). output ANOVA table means tables main effects interactions, shows post hoc results comparing effects first named condition levels second.    Finally, IAT function `gorilla_iatanalysis()` processing analysis task data ’ve done one step.
code: anv <- afex::aov_ez(data=iat_data[accuracy==1 & rt<2000],fun_aggregate = mean,                     id="pid",between="firstblock",within="congruency",dv="rt")  plot_model(anv,outp = NULL,bars=F) # you can pass pirateye parameters to this function ##  ## Univariate Type III Repeated-Measures ANOVA Assuming Sphericity ##  ##                         Sum Sq num Df Error SS den Df  F value  Pr(>F)     ## (Intercept)           34517501      1  1727205     26 519.5995 < 2e-16 *** ## firstblock               26906      1  1727205     26   0.4050 0.53007     ## congruency               87704      1   223885     26  10.1851 0.00368 **  ## firstblock:congruency     8705      1   223885     26   1.0109 0.32396     ## --- ## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 ##  ##  ## Main effects of  congruency  ##  congruency  emmean   SE df lower.CL upper.CL ##  congruent      825 38.0 26      747      903 ##  incongruent    913 42.9 26      825     1001 ##  ## Results are averaged over the levels of: firstblock  ## Confidence level used: 0.95  ##  contrast                estimate   SE df t.ratio p.value ##  congruent - incongruent    -87.6 27.4 26  -3.191  0.0037 ##  ## Results are averaged over the levels of: firstblock ##  ##  ## Main effects of  firstblock  ##  firstblock  emmean   SE df lower.CL upper.CL ##  congruent      893 40.8 26      809      977 ##  incongruent    845 64.4 26      712      977 ##  ## Results are averaged over the levels of: congruency  ## Confidence level used: 0.95  ##  contrast                estimate   SE df t.ratio p.value ##  congruent - incongruent     48.5 76.2 26   0.636  0.5301 ##  ## Results are averaged over the levels of: congruency ##  ##  ## Interactions of  congruency firstblock  ##  congruency  firstblock  emmean   SE df lower.CL upper.CL ##  congruent   congruent      836 40.6 26      752      919 ##  incongruent congruent      951 45.9 26      856     1045 ##  congruent   incongruent    815 64.2 26      683      947 ##  incongruent incongruent    875 72.6 26      726     1024 ##  ## Confidence level used: 0.95  ##  contrast                                        estimate   SE df t.ratio ##  congruent congruent - incongruent congruent       -115.2 29.3 26  -3.926 ##  congruent congruent - congruent incongruent         20.9 75.9 26   0.276 ##  congruent congruent - incongruent incongruent      -39.1 83.1 26  -0.470 ##  incongruent congruent - congruent incongruent      136.1 78.9 26   1.726 ##  incongruent congruent - incongruent incongruent     76.1 85.8 26   0.887 ##  congruent incongruent - incongruent incongruent    -60.0 46.4 26  -1.293 ##  p.value ##   0.0030 ##   0.9925 ##   0.9650 ##   0.3312 ##   0.8117 ##   0.5753 ##  ## P value adjustment: tukey method for comparing a family of 4 estimates ## $model_summary ##  ## Univariate Type III Repeated-Measures ANOVA Assuming Sphericity ##  ##                         Sum Sq num Df Error SS den Df  F value  Pr(>F)     ## (Intercept)           34517501      1  1727205     26 519.5995 < 2e-16 *** ## firstblock               26906      1  1727205     26   0.4050 0.53007     ## congruency               87704      1   223885     26  10.1851 0.00368 **  ## firstblock:congruency     8705      1   223885     26   1.0109 0.32396     ## --- ## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 ##  ## $means_congruency ##  congruency  emmean   SE df lower.CL upper.CL ##  congruent      825 38.0 26      747      903 ##  incongruent    913 42.9 26      825     1001 ##  ## Results are averaged over the levels of: firstblock  ## Confidence level used: 0.95  ##  ## $plot_congruency ##  ## $means_firstblock ##  firstblock  emmean   SE df lower.CL upper.CL ##  congruent      893 40.8 26      809      977 ##  incongruent    845 64.4 26      712      977 ##  ## Results are averaged over the levels of: congruency  ## Confidence level used: 0.95  ##  ## $plot_firstblock ##  ## $means_congruency_firstblock ##  congruency  firstblock  emmean   SE df lower.CL upper.CL ##  congruent   congruent      836 40.6 26      752      919 ##  incongruent congruent      951 45.9 26      856     1045 ##  congruent   incongruent    815 64.2 26      683      947 ##  incongruent incongruent    875 72.6 26      726     1024 ##  ## Confidence level used: 0.95  ##  ## $plot_congruency_firstblock gorilla_iatanalysis(data)

title: eyethinkdata_vignette
text: various functions processing questionnaire data begin gorill_q. specialised particular surveys, TIPI personality test BMIS mood scale. Others help code fiddly things like rank scores checkboxes. basic gorilla_q function just parses answers questions survey outputs one row per participant. Gorilla gives text answers quanitzed form . don’t need can strip strip=“quant” (conversely “qual”). leave qlist blank, run task.names gorilla data_q, can specifc one questionnaire . powerful function lets use key score survey, useful lots reversed scored items, subscales calculate. one, gorilla questionnaire name “Interpersonal Reactivity Index (Davies, 1983)”, can name qlist. generate blank survey key save working directory folder called ‘survey_key’. looks like. can edit excel text editor, save .csv file.row every different survey item gorilla questionnaire, row identified Question.Key - wrote ‘key’ box making survey gorilla. order tells appeared gorilla (NA randomised). can change numbers columns sum, ScaleNam, Subscore qual, score/summarize survey. ’s columns mean: sum - item contributes scoring: set 1 add , -1 reverse score. enter 0 answer won’t used compute score, instead answer reported column rev - reversed scored, subtract answer number. eg assuming 7 point scale, ’ve set 8 default. ScaleName - end one row per person variable name (eg IQ) summarizing items. can one many different scales questionnaire key Subscore - can break scales subscales. Name also appear output scored column (eg IQ_verbal) qual - item non numeric qualitative response (eg text box) put 1 . won’t summarized till also reported output column. ignore - response matches answer, don’t use scale calculation. used, eg scales 1-7 answer, people can also enter 8 ‘applicable’. ’s filled version Interpersonal Reactivity Scale key Now can parse score questionnaire using function. get output one row per person, one column scores answers, additionally columns subscales text answers.
code: gorilla_q_parse(data,qlist = "basic demographics",strip="quant" ) ##          pid    Sex   age ##       <fctr> <char> <num> ##  1:  3735601   Male    58 ##  2:  2874231   Male    51 ##  3:  2878349   Male    53 ##  4:  2887782 Female    24 ##  5:  2902933 Female    45 ##  6:  2906179 Female    22 ##  7:  2912330 Female    37 ##  8:  2921282   Male    41 ##  9:  2921652   Male    38 ## 10:  3730237 Female    57 ## 11:  3731661 Female    38 ## 12:  3734675 Female    51 ## 13:  3734775 Female    42 ## 14:  5891983 Female    41 ## 15: 10068596 Female    23 ## 16: 10106060 Female    44 ## 17: 10110660 Female    35 ## 18: 10107554   Male    29 gorilla_q_keyed(data,qlist= "Interpersonal Reactivity Index (Davies, 1983)",keyout = T) ## There is no key for: Interpersonal Reactivity Index (Davies, 1983)  ## ... so I put a key for Interpersonal Reactivity Index (Davies, 1983) in working directory for you to edit ##                                         Task.Name order Question.Key   sum ##                                            <char> <int>       <char> <num> ##  1: Interpersonal Reactivity Index (Davies, 1983)     1         EC_1     1 ##  2: Interpersonal Reactivity Index (Davies, 1983)     2         PT_1     1 ##  3: Interpersonal Reactivity Index (Davies, 1983)     3         EC_2     1 ##  4: Interpersonal Reactivity Index (Davies, 1983)     4         PT_2     1 ##  5: Interpersonal Reactivity Index (Davies, 1983)     5         EC_3     1 ##  6: Interpersonal Reactivity Index (Davies, 1983)     6         PT_3     1 ##  7: Interpersonal Reactivity Index (Davies, 1983)     7         EC_4     1 ##  8: Interpersonal Reactivity Index (Davies, 1983)     8         PT_4     1 ##  9: Interpersonal Reactivity Index (Davies, 1983)     9         EC_5     1 ## 10: Interpersonal Reactivity Index (Davies, 1983)    10         EC_6     1 ## 11: Interpersonal Reactivity Index (Davies, 1983)    11         PT_5     1 ## 12: Interpersonal Reactivity Index (Davies, 1983)    12         EC_7     1 ## 13: Interpersonal Reactivity Index (Davies, 1983)    13         PT_6     1 ## 14: Interpersonal Reactivity Index (Davies, 1983)    14         PT_7     1 ##       rev scaleName Subscore  qual ignore ##     <num>    <char>   <char> <num> <lgcl> ##  1:     8      IRID              0     NA ##  2:     8      IRID              0     NA ##  3:     8      IRID              0     NA ##  4:     8      IRID              0     NA ##  5:     8      IRID              0     NA ##  6:     8      IRID              0     NA ## 12:     8      IRID              0     NA ## 13:     8      IRID              0     NA ## 14:     8      IRID              0     NA read.csv("survey_key complete/Interpersonal Reactivity Index (Davies, 1983).csv") ## 3  Interpersonal Reactivity Index (Davies, 1983)         EC_2  -1   6      ECPT ## 4  Interpersonal Reactivity Index (Davies, 1983)         PT_2   1   6      ECPT ## 5  Interpersonal Reactivity Index (Davies, 1983)         EC_3   1   6      ECPT ## title: Tools for processing behavioural data
Tools for processing behavioural data
text: toolbox behavioural data. processes raw downloads gorilla, preps behavioural datas analysis extracts scores information questionnaires. Performs basic plotting RDIs (pirate plots), correlations raw data ANOVAs mixed models. Use code install update github vignette walk using package functions. can access R can also read online github website.
code: devtools::install_github("dcr-eyethink/eyethinkdata") library(eyethinkdata) vignette("eyethinkdata_vignette",package = "eyethinkdata")

ScaleName - end one row per person variable name (eg IQ) summarizing items. can one many different scales questionnaire key Subscore  - can break scales subscales. Name also appear output scored column (eg IQ_verbal) qual - item non numeric qualitative response (eg text box) put 1 . summarized till also reported output column ignore - response matches answer, use scale calculation. used, eg, scales 1-7 answer want code, people can also enter 8 'applicable'.

title: Outputs a pirate plot (RDI) — pirateye
code: pirateye(   data,   colour_condition = NULL,   x_condition = "variable",   facet_condition = NULL,   facet_scales = "fixed",   facet_row = NULL,   pid_average = F,   dv,   reorder = F,   pid = "pid",   dodgewidth = 0.8,   plot_condition = NULL,   cond = NULL,   cond2 = NULL,   facetby = NULL,   ylim = NULL,   xlim = NULL,   w = NULL,   h = 6,   title = NULL,   outp = "analysis",   cols = NULL,   pred_line = F,   error_bar_data = NULL,   ypercent = F,   x_axis = NULL,   y_axis = NULL,   error_dim = F,   error_dim_value = 0,   pred = NULL,   pred_means = NULL,   pred_bar = T,   xlabs = NULL,   xlabpos = 0.7,   error_data = NULL,   cflip = F,   norm = F,   bars = F,   violin = T,   dots = T,   splitV = F,   svw = 1,   dot_h_jitter = 0,   line = F,   error_bars = T,   useall = F,   legend = T,   title_overide = F,   combine_plots = list(),   combine_position = "right",   elementinc = NULL,   type = NULL,   ... )

title: Outputs a pirate plot (RDI) — pirateye
text: data data one person per line, excluding rows use=0 colour_condition colour split x_condition x axis split (, specified colour condition used x axis ) facet_condition faceting pid_average plot average participant's dv named conditions dv name single dv column, multiple columns, case split x_condition unless colour facet condition set 'variable' pid whats name col identifies individuals plot_condition instead passing individually, can give vector 3 cols specify colours use, can set colours, condition_level colour ypercent Convert y scale x_axistitles y_axistitles xlabposHow high vertically , proportion plot height error_datadistribution mean, eg Bayes analysis, replace SE cflipflip horizontal plot normnormalise / z-score values comparison across scales useallignore use column plot rows typeshortcuts: m=just error bars, b=just bars xlabDo labels go across x axis, post hoc pvalues MPEs Defaults violin plot error bars dots, elements dots, bars, violin, error_bars can turned
